question: A patient at 22 weeks gestation is diagnosed as having IUD which occurred at 17 weeks but did not have a miscarriage. The patient is at increased risk of:
exp: Dead fetus if retained for more than 4-5 weeks, release thromboplastin which leads to DIC Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 304.

question: The complications of shoulder presentations are all of the following except
exp: Complications of shoulder presentation Cord prolapse Tonic contraction of uterus Obstructed labor Rupture of uterus

question: The following statements are related to occipito posterior except
exp: In more than 50% the occipito posterior position is associated with either anthrapoid or android pelvis
opa: Malrotation of occiput may cause occipito sacral arrest
opb: 10% cases are associated with anthrapoid or android pelvis
opc: Incomplete forward rotation of occiput may cause deep transverse arrest
opd: Non rotation of occiput may cause are associated

question: In deep transverse arrest, all of the following can be done except:
exp: Deep transeverse arrest occurs at the level of ischial spine and hence it cannot be managed by wrigleys forceps which is an outlet forceps basically and forceps cannot rotate the head of body except kielland forceps

question: Procedure to be performed in the case of arrest of after coming head due to contracted pelvis in breech
exp: The last rescue for entrapped fetal head in term fetus is replacement of the fetus higher into the vagina and uterus followed by cesarean delivery this is zavanelli maneuver

question: In pregnant women of 28 weeks gestation IUD is earliest demonstrated on X-ray by:
exp: Gas in the great vessels of fetus is called as Robes sign It occurs 12 hrs interval after death. Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 303.

question: All of the following are features of obstructed labour except:
exp: In case of obstructed labour: Membranes are ruptured Vagina is hot and dry Foul smelling discharge Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 380.

question: The complications that can occur with internal podalic version for transverse lie:
exp: Internal podalic version: It is used for the second twin when it is lying transversely and external version fails Complications: Maternal Placental abruption Rupture uterus Increase morbidity Fetal Asphyxia Cord prolapse Intracranial hemorrhage Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 543.

question: In after coming head the following bone is perforated during craniotomy
exp: Craniotomy is perforating the fetal skull and evacuating the contents and then delivering the fetal pas. In after coming head in breech occipital bone is the perforation site

question: Forceps should not be used in:
exp: One of the criteria before applying forceps - There should be no major cephalopelvic dispropoion by clinical pelvimetry Hydrocephalus is a most common cause of CPD. Ref: Dutta Obs 9e pg 533.

question: In a patient with history of previous still bih, optimum time of delivery is:
exp: All the females who have previous H/o still bih, the optimum time of delivery is 39 weeks and the mode of delivery is vaginal delivery. Ref: Williams Obs 25e pg 649.

question: A second para is admitted in advanced labor at a period of amenorrhea of 40weeks. she has a single fetus in transverse lie. The fetal hea beat is absent. On vaginal examination the cervix is fully dilated. The presenting pa is shoulder. What is the most appropriate management?
exp: In this case patient is presenting in advanced labor with IUD and transverse lie. Management is immediate cesaream section
opa: Await spontaneous delivery of the dead fetus

question: In case of unstable lie of fetus, the placenta is usually:
exp: Unstable lie is seen in placenta pre. Other conditions include: Multipara Hydramnios Contracted pelvis Pelvic tumor Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 372.

question: The complications of shoulder presentations are all of the following except:
exp: In neglected shoulder presentation there is a increased fetal loss due to: Cord prolapse Tonic contraction of uterus /Obstructed labour Rupture of uterus Shoulder dystocia is not a complication of neglected shoulder presentation. Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 370.

question: ECV is absolutely contraindicated in all except:
exp: Absolute contraindication of ECV: Placenta pre Multiple pregnancies H/o antepaum hemorrhage IUGR Severe pre-eclampsia and hypertension Rupture of membranes Known uterine malformation Ref: Williams Obs 24e pg 570.

question: Deep transverse arrest is seen in all except
exp: Causes of deep transverse arrest Android pelvis Depression of head Weak uterine contractions Laxity of pelvic floor muscles

question: Face to pubis delivery occurs in which position?
exp: Face to pubis delivery is done in occipito posterior position head rotates posteriorly and becomes direct occipito posterior position

question: Best method to deliver arms in breech:
exp: Lovset's method: The baby is lifted slightly to cause lateral flexion. The trunk is rotated through 180deg keeping the back anterior and maintaining a downward traction. This brings the posterior arm to emerge under the pubic arch which is then hooked out The trunk is then rotated in reverse direction keeping the back anterior to deliver the anterior shoulder under the symphysis pubis Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 363.

question: Which statement is true regarding Ventouse (vacuum extractor):
exp: Maternal trauma is less in vacuum than in forceps. Vacuum promote autorotation. So, it can be used in unrotated or malrotated occipitoposterior position of the head Ref: Dutta Obs 9e pg 539.
opa: Minor scalp abrasion and Subgaleal hematomas in newborn are more frequent than forceps
opb: Can be applied when fetal head is above the level of ischial spine
opc: Maternal trauma is more frequent than forceps
opd: Cannot be used when fetal head is not fully rotated

question: A 40 year old primipara who has been infeile for 12 years attends the antenatal clinic of 37 weeks. The fetus is in breech presentation. The estimated fetal weight is 3 kg. The pregnancy is otherwise uncomplicated. The pelvis is adequate. What is the best management option?
exp: In this case pregnancy is very precious as this female has been infeile for 12 years and then conceived, hnece ECV should not be done and elective cesarean section should be done at 39 weeks
opa: Await spontaneous onset of labor and normal vaginal delivery
opb: Perform a cesarean section at 39 weeks
opc: Perform a cesarean section, if labor becomes prolonged

question: Procedure to be performed in the case of arrest of after coming head due to contracted pelvis in breech:
exp: Zavanelli maneuver: The last rescue for entrapped fetal head in term fetus is replacement of fetus higher into the vagina and uterus followed by cesarean section. Ref: Williams Obs 24e pg 567.

question: Spalding's ring is seen in:
exp: Spalding sign: It is the irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another, due to liquefication of brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures suppoing the vault. Appears 7 days after death. Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 303.

question: ECV is absolutely contraindicated in all except
exp: Absolute contraindications for ECV Placenta pre Multiple pregnancies IUGR history of antepaum hemorrhage Severe preeclampsia Rupture of membranes Uterine malformations

question: A forceps rotation of 30deg from left occiput anterior (LOA) to occiput anterior (OA) with extraction of fetus from +2station is described as which type of forceps delivery?
exp: Presence of fetal head at +2station indicate low forceps delivery. High forceps -head not engaged Mid cavity forceps-head engaged, presenting pa above +2station Low forceps -head at +2or below it but not at reached pelvic flow Outlet-head at or on perineum. Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 533, table 37. 2

question: The after coming head of breech, chin to pubis is delivered by:
exp: Sometimes in Breech presentation, the after coming head rotates posteriorly so that face is behind pubis, this condition is difficult to deliver and is called Chin to pubis rotation In this situation, manual rotation of fetal head and trunk is done as in malar flexion and shoulder traction and then head is delivered with forceps. In case of premature baby, the delivery of head may be completed as face to pubis by reversed malar flexion and shoulder traction or by forceps. Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 363, Williams Obs 23e pg 537.
opd: Manual rotation and extraction by Piper's forceps

question: Blood in urine in labour is diagnostic of:
exp: In obstructed labour, bladder becomes an abdominal organ due to compression of urethra between the presenting pa and symphysis pubis - patient fails to empty the bladder The transverse depression at the junction of superior border of the bladder and distended lower segment is confused with the Bandl's ring The bladder wall get traumatized which may lead to blood stained urine, a common finding in obstructed labour Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 379.

question: In case of direct occipito posterior position most commonly encountered problem is
exp: In face to pubis delivery the most common complication is perineal tear as the occiput is posterior and thus the longer biparietal diameter distends the perineum rather than the smaller bitemporal diameter. Hence in all such cases liberal episotomy should be given

question: The most common form of fetal traumatic injury incurred during extraction is
exp: The most frequent single cause of death in breech presentation is intracranial hemorrhage due to tentorial tears, these tears are the result of sudden excessive pressure on the after coming head and may be aptly described as the snapping of the internal greyropes of the cranium

question: On external cephalic version, fetal bradycardia occurred. The next course of action is:
exp: External cephalic version: Is done to bring orable cephalic pole in the lower pole of uterus Indications: Breech presentation Transverse lie Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 542.
opa: Reversion to the original position immediately by external version

question: 38 weeks primi in early labour with transverse presentation, TOC is:
exp: Elective cesarean section is preferred method of delivery, because of risk of early rupture of membranes and cord prolapse. Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 372.

question: Techniques of delivery of after coming head in breech presentation include all except:
exp: Methods of delivery of after coming head of breech: Burns-Marshall technique Mauriceau Smellie Viet technique Piper's forceps Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 360.

question: Traction force required for forceps delivery in primigravida is:
exp: Traction force required by forceps is: Primigravida -18-20 kgs Multigravida-13 kgs Vacuum - initial pressure is 0. 2 kg/cm2 induced over 2 minutes. The pressure is gradually increased at the rate of 0. 1 kg/cm2 to a maximum of 0. 8 kg/cm2. Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 533.

question: A 30 years old primipara in labour with transverse lie, treatment of choice is:
exp: Patient in labour with transverse lie can be managed by external cephalic version followed by surgical rupture of the membrane. But it is impoant to note that the patient is a primigravida with 30 years, i. e, elderly primi so ECV is contraindicated So this patient requires an emergency cesarean section. Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 372, Williams Obs 23e pg 478.

question: In case of IVD with transverse are, following can be done
exp: Management of transverse lie and IUD is done best by ceserean section and others like evisceration and decapitation

question: Which is the most likely complication of IUD?
exp: Complications of IUD: Psychological upset Uterine infections Blood coagulation disorder Hypofibrogenemia occurs due to gradual absorption of thromboplastin, liberated from the dead placenta and decides. Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 304.

question: In transverse lie presentation is
exp: In transverse lie shoulder presentation is seen

question: Deep transverse arrest is seen in all except:
exp: Deep transverse arrest is a complication of occipitoposterior position, how can it occur in transverse lie. Causes of deep transverse arrest: Faulty pelvic architecture Depression of head Weak uterine contractions Laxity of pelvic floor muscles In transverse lie, presenting pa is shoulder, so deep transverse arrest doesn't occur. Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 349.

question: In which fetal presentation vaginal delivery can be expected?
exp: Vaginal delivery is not possible in Brow presentation Shoulder presentation Mentoposterior presentation of face
opa: Face presentation when the chin lies direct to the sacrum
opd: Face presentation when the chin lies under the symphsis pubis

question: The following statements are related to occipitoposterior except:
exp: Occipitoposterior position: In more than 50% of occipitoposterior position is associated with anthropoid or android pelvis Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 343.
opa: Malrotation of occiput may cause occipitoacral arrest
opb: 10% cases are associated with anthropoid or android pelvis
opc: Incomplete forward rotation of occiput may cause deep transverse arrest
opd: Non rotation of occiput may cause

question: The following is always an indication of cesarean section except:
exp: Cesarean section is not indicated in all cases of situation placentae. In carcinoma cervix, vaginal delivery should not be allowed because of cervical dystocia and injuries Cesarean section is indicated in an active primary genital HSV infection where the membranes are intact or recently ruptured In severe degree of placenta pre cesarean section is indicated for maternal interest even if baby is dead. Ref: Dutta Obs 9e pg 242, 235, 282, 288.

question: In left oblique breech presentation head engages in
exp: Head in breech engages in opposite oblique diameter as that occupied by buttocks. since breech is in left oblique hence head will engage in right oblique diameter

question: Incase of unstable lie of fetus the placenta is usually
exp: Unstable lie is seen in placenta pre

question: In an after coming head the following bone is perforated during craniotomy:
exp: Craniotomy: It consists of perforating the fetal skull, evacuating the contents and then delivering rest of the fetal pas Indications: Delivery of dead fetus in obstructed labour with a cephalic presentation Delivery of the arrested after coming head in vaginal breech delivery Hydrocephalus Ref: Datta Obs 9e pg 544.

question: A 30 year old primipara in labor with transverse lie treatment of choice is
exp: Patients in labor with transverse lie can be managed by external cephalic version followed by surgical rupture of membrane But it is impoant to note that the patient is primigravuda with age 30years i. e, elderly primi so ECV is contraindicated This patient requires emergency cesaream section

question: Least chances of cord prolapse are seen with
exp: Maximum chances of cord prolapse seen in breech are in footling where as min chances in frank frank breech
